title: Letters: Coalition's own Grapes of Wrath
text:
Give small business more notice, Treasurer

If Treasurer Josh Frydenberg is thinking of doing something on depreciation for small business he needs to signal it early. That allows business to consider where best to put their money. An announcement near the end of the tax year encourages individuals to invest for the wrong reason – tax minimisation, not business development.

Iain MacPhedran

Helensburgh, NSW

The Iraqi blot on Howard’s record

In a recent interview marking the 75th anniversary of the foundation of the Liberal Party, John Howard refused to acknowledge that committing forces to Iraq was a “misjudgment”.

In reality, Howard’s decision to join the US and Britain in the invasion of Iraq was a disaster, justified at the time by claims, suspect even then, that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction.

The invasion cost hundreds of thousands of lives and billions of dollars, and, arguably, it was an underlying cause of the regional instability that led to the rise of IS.

John Howard was one of our most successful prime ministers and there is much he and his government can be proud of. Iraq, however, was a terrible mistake, and it would be refreshing if he finally owned up to it.

Paul Carberry

Plympton, SA

Too much overreach is barely enough

Alexander Downer would presumably extend his argument in ‘‘The overreach of well-meaning global bureaucrats’’ (October 7) to national bureaucrats.

After all, they’re the ones who impose on us rules about what side of the road to drive on, whether we can walk into someone else’s house and take what we want, or manufacture poisonous products and trick others into buying them, and so on. They also give us our financial system, our legal system, etc.

We don’t accept cowboy capitalism nationally, so why should we accept it internationally? Answer: because a productive society – and especially one we want to live in – can’t work that way.

Darian Hiles

Adelaide, SA

Democracy’s not about keeping quiet

There’s a dangerous pattern of intolerance and intimidation emerging from the Morrison government when it comes to not-so-quiet Australians and international organisations challenging or criticising the government’s policies and actions.

This pattern is dangerous because it undermines fundamental democratic processes and deters people from speaking out against injustice, corruption, malpractice or poor policies and decision-making. Frankly, it is tantamount to authoritarianism.

That such attitudes and actions arise from the most senior levels of the government should be a concern for all Australians who believe they are living in a democracy.

Mark Beavis

Mount Evelyn, Vic

Franking credits cut: good policy badly sold

The ALP seems intent on blaming its policy of abolishing franking credit refunds as a major contributor to its election loss (‘‘Albo’s 2022 plan’’, October 8). This is a great injustice because reversing an abominable piece of legislation passed under the Howard/Costello government some years ago was and is good policy. Its apparent failure at the last election was due more to Labor’s inability to explain how it would benefit the millions of working Australians.

Ross Kelly

Bracken Ridge, Qld

Climate backdown won’t save Labor

Is Joel Fitzgibbon serious, wanting to mimic the government’s climate change “policy” so the ALP can win the next election? Apparently it hasn’t occurred to Mr Fitzgibbon that voters didn’t see enough difference between his party and the Coalition in May to warrant changing.

It’s no surprise that he is promoting such a non-policy though, given his electorate’s relationship to coal. We might as well wave goodbye to a clean future with these parties ruling politics.

Catherine Moore

Braidwood, NSW
